column1: Salmonella enterocolitis is an infection in the lining of the small intestine that is caused by Salmonella bacteria.

You are more likely to get this type of infection if you have: - Eaten foods such as turkey, turkey dressing, chicken, or eggs that have not been cooked well or stored properly - Family members with a recent salmonella infection - Been or worked in a hospital, nursing home, or other long-term health facility - A pet iguana or other lizards, turtles, or snakes (reptiles and amphibians are carriers of salmonella) - A weakened immune system - Regularly used medicines that block acid production in the stomach - Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis - Used antibiotics in the recent past Most people with this condition are younger than 20.
The health care provider will perform a physical exam.
